html:
The choice to get out of bed and go for a morning run in winter is qualitatively different to the same in summer.

On these dark mornings, my tired brain does something to accentuate the
softness of the duvet on the skin of my cheek, and I feel like I am
literally a different person to the one who set my alarm last night - a
masochist with the torturous intention of exposing my extremities to the
cold, not-really-even-daytime-yet air. On the days that I don't press
snooze and curse my shortsighted alarm-setting behaviour of the night
before, I drag myself out of bed, fasten my sneakers that I simultaneously
love and hate, walk to the gate trying not to wake the sleeping house of
both humans and dogs, and enter the cold, feeling somewhat astonished that
I am actually doing this.

There are a few different routes I know, and I'll decide to run this one or
that depending on how I feel. They all begin in the particular Northern suburb
of Johannesburg now notoriously associated with state capture.
Within the first 10 minutes, I am almost guaranteed to run past a fellow
runner, or a flock of cyclists, or a group of ducklike walkers - quacking
and flapping around their wings as they plod on. Probably all live in, or
very close to, the old suburb of Saxonwold, and most likely believe that a
morning exercise routine is key to a successful and happy day.

As I make my way under trees, and past strong walls with electric fences
towards Rosebank, I begin to encounter a wider diversity of passers-by. I
see couples of old women, laughing, carrying two or three heavy parcels
each. I see groups of men walking fast in blue overalls. I see single men
in brown overalls trying to keep track of the leashes of five or so dogs,
holding on strongly but not quite assertively. None own dogs themselves, or
houses, or bicycles in Saxonwold.

I always wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy
parcels think of me, trotting past them, saying 'Good Morning' and 'I'm
sorry', having chosen to run in the wicked cold - partly because I really
do enjoy running, and partly because I really do enjoy the Berry Dairy
smoothies to which running entitles me (thanks, Discovery Vitality). I
wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy parcels think
of the flocks of cyclists and the ducklike walkers. I wonder whether the
flocks of cyclists, who I've heard barking with rage as they whiz past the
Gupta mansion, are as stirred by the Gupta's impact on the lives of the men
in overalls walking behind them.

The men in overalls are most often young men. Perhaps if they had gone to
university, they would have graduated a year before me. I imagine what
music they might like. Sometimes I think of asking them, but I never do. I
imagine they are on their way to construct a building for someone who may
as well be a cyclist, a walker, a runner.





On Sat, 9 Jun 2018 at 12:11, Natasha Salant <natashasalant@gmail.com> wrote:

masochist with the torturous intention of exposing my extremities to the
cold, not-really-even-daytime-yet air. On the days that I don't press
snooze and curse my shortsighted alarm-setting behaviour of the night
before, I drag myself out of bed, fasten my sneakers that I simultaneously
love and hate, walk to the gate trying not to wake the sleeping house of
both humans and dogs, and enter the cold, feeling somewhat astonished that
I am actually doing this.

There are a few different routes I know, and I'll decide to run this one or
that depending on how I feel. They all begin in the particular Northern suburb 
of Johannesburg now notoriously associated with state capture. 
Within the first 10 minutes, I am almost guaranteed to run past a fellow
runner, or a flock of cyclists, or a group of ducklike walkers - quacking
and flapping around their wings as they plod on. Probably all live in, or
very close to, the old suburb of Saxonwold, and most likely believe that a
morning exercise routine is key to a successful and happy day.

As I make my way under trees, and past strong walls with electric fences
towards Rosebank, I begin to encounter a wider diversity of passers-by. I
see couples of old women, laughing, carrying two or three heavy parcels
each. I see groups of men walking fast in blue overalls. I see single men
in brown overalls trying to keep track of the leashes of five or so dogs,
holding on strongly but not quite assertively. None own dogs themselves, or
houses, or bicycles in Saxonwold.

I always wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy
parcels think of me, trotting past them, saying 'Good Morning' and 'I'm
sorry', having chosen to run in the wicked cold - partly because I really
do enjoy running, and partly because I really do enjoy the Berry Dairy
smoothies to which running entitles me (thanks, Discovery Vitality). I
wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy parcels think
of the flocks of cyclists and the ducklike walkers. I wonder whether the
flocks of cyclists, who I've heard barking with rage as they whiz past the
Gupta mansion, are as stirred by the Gupta's impact on the lives of the men
in overalls walking behind them.

The men in overalls are most often young men. Perhaps if they had gone to
university, they would have graduated a year before me. I imagine what
music they might like. Sometimes I think of asking them, but I never do. I
imagine they are on their way to construct a building for someone who may
as well be a cyclist, a walker, a runner.





--
Best, 
Natasha Salant

text:
The choice to get out of bed and go for a morning run in winter is
qualitatively different to the same in summer.

On these dark mornings, my tired brain does something to accentuate the
softness of the duvet on the skin of my cheek, and I feel like I am
literally a different person to the one who set my alarm last night - a
masochist with the torturous intention of exposing my extremities to the
cold, not-really-even-daytime-yet air. On the days that I don't press
snooze and curse my shortsighted alarm-setting behaviour of the night
before, I drag myself out of bed, fasten my sneakers that I simultaneously
love and hate, walk to the gate trying not to wake the sleeping house of
both humans and dogs, and enter the cold, feeling somewhat astonished that
I am actually doing this.

There are a few different routes I know, and I'll decide to run this one or
that depending on how I feel. They all begin in the particular Northern
suburb
of Johannesburg now notoriously associated with state capture.
Within the first 10 minutes, I am almost guaranteed to run past a fellow
runner, or a flock of cyclists, or a group of ducklike walkers - quacking
and flapping around their wings as they plod on. Probably all live in, or
very close to, the old suburb of Saxonwold, and most likely believe that a
morning exercise routine is key to a successful and happy day.

As I make my way under trees, and past strong walls with electric fences
towards Rosebank, I begin to encounter a wider diversity of passers-by. I
see couples of old women, laughing, carrying two or three heavy parcels
each. I see groups of men walking fast in blue overalls. I see single men
in brown overalls trying to keep track of the leashes of five or so dogs,
holding on strongly but not quite assertively. None own dogs themselves, or
houses, or bicycles in Saxonwold.

I always wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy
parcels think of me, trotting past them, saying 'Good Morning' and 'I'm
sorry', having chosen to run in the wicked cold - partly because I really
do enjoy running, and partly because I really do enjoy the Berry Dairy
smoothies to which running entitles me (thanks, Discovery Vitality). I
wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy parcels think
of the flocks of cyclists and the ducklike walkers. I wonder whether the
flocks of cyclists, who I've heard barking with rage as they whiz past the
Gupta mansion, are as stirred by the Gupta's impact on the lives of the men
in overalls walking behind them.

The men in overalls are most often young men. Perhaps if they had gone to
university, they would have graduated a year before me. I imagine what
music they might like. Sometimes I think of asking them, but I never do. I
imagine they are on their way to construct a building for someone who may
as well be a cyclist, a walker, a runner.

> Within the first 10 minutes, I am almost guaranteed to run past a fellow

>
> I always wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy

> wonder what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy parcels think

> imagine they are on their way to construct a building for someone who may
> as well be a cyclist, a walker, a runner.
>
>

Best,
Natasha Salant

before, I drag myself out of bed, fasten my sneake= rs that I simultaneously
love and hate, walk to the gate trying not to w= ake the sleeping house of
both humans and dogs, and enter the cold, feel= ing somewhat astonished that
I am actually doing this.

There are = a few different routes I know, and I'll decide to run this one or
th= at depending on how I feel. They all begin in the particular Northern subur= b
of Johannesburg now notoriously associated with state capture.
With= in the first 10 minutes, I am almost guaranteed to run past a fellow
run= ner, or a flock of cyclists, or a group of ducklike walkers - quacking
a= nd flapping around their wings as they plod on. Probably all live in, orvery close to, the old suburb of Saxonwold, and most likely believe that a=
morning exercise routine is key to a successful and happy day.

A= s I make my way under trees, and past strong walls with electric fences
= towards Rosebank, I begin to encounter a wider diversity of passers-by. Isee couples of old women, laughing, carrying two or three heavy parcelseach. I see groups of men walking fast in blue overalls. I see single men=
in brown overalls trying to keep track of the leashes of five or so dog= s,
holding on strongly but not quite assertively. None own dogs themselv= es, or
houses, or bicycles in Saxonwold.

I always wonder what the= men in overalls and the women with the heavy
parcels think of me, trott= ing past them, saying 'Good Morning' and 'I'm
sorry'= , having chosen to run in the wicked cold - partly because I really
do e= njoy running, and partly because I really do enjoy the Berry Dairy
smoot= hies to which running entitles me (thanks, Discovery Vitality). I
wonder= what the men in overalls and the women with the heavy parcels think
of = the flocks of cyclists and the ducklike walkers. I wonder whether the
fl= ocks of cyclists, who I've heard barking with rage as they whiz past th= e
Gupta mansion, are as stirred by the Gupta's impact on the lives o= f the men
in overalls walking behind them.

The men in overalls ar= e most often young men. Perhaps if they had gone to
university, they wou= ld have graduated a year before me. I imagine what
music they might like= . Sometimes I think of asking them, but I never do. I
imagine they are o= n their way to construct a building for someone who may
as well be a cyc= list, a walker, a runner.
